frontmatter.doctitle: Avocado cravings cannot be satisfied; imported more than billion euros in 'green gold'

level1.h1: Avocado cravings cannot be satisfied; imported more than billion euros in 'green gold'
level1.p:
No fruit is becoming more popular as quickly as the avocado. Last year, 1.1 billion euros worth of avocados were imported, according to figures from the Central Bureau of Statistics. It is now the number 1 of the fruits that come from abroad, if you look at the value of the fruit. With that, the avocado is over bananas, grapes and oranges.
The Dutch eat much more avocados than before, an average of twelve avocados per year. That is almost four times as many as in 2008. Nevertheless, the popularity in other countries in particular leads to more and more of this fruit being imported. More than 90 percent of all avocados that come to the Netherlands are re-exported to other European countries.
This makes the Netherlands the avocado hub of Europe. It is the largest avocado exporter of any country that does not grow avocados themselves.
Mango or avocado Nature's Pride in Maasdijk is one of the companies that ripen avocados. It started fifteen years ago and then tried to increase its popularity.
"We then started telling consumers in supermarkets that avocado is very tasty, they let them taste guacamole", says Adriëlle Dankier, commercial director of the company. She herself was in supermarkets to sell the fruit.
"We actually thought mangos would become more popular than avocados, but the versatility of avocado has kept it growing."
Each week, 1.5 million kilos of avocados enter the company. The company supplies to 28 countries, mainly Germany and Scandinavia. Some of the avocados have recently been given an extra protective layer so that they have a longer shelf life.
According to the company, the stretch is far from out of growth. "Just over 30 percent of all people buy avocados," says Dankier. "We expect growth to continue. We are expanding and working on new additions."
Tortilla chips Most avocados come from Peru, Chile, Colombia, South Africa and Mexico. Due to the increased demand for the 'green gold', more and more farmers are focusing on the cultivation of the fruit. This is criticized, because a lot of water is needed to grow avocados and forests are being cut down for it.
Last year, researcher Manuel Ochoa Ayala called on the World Economic Forum website to consider this as a consumer. "What you eat with friends and family can devastate entire ecosystems. Think about that the next time you eat tortilla chips with guacamole dip."
Production line in Maasdijk NOS
Nature's Pride says it works with growers to produce sustainably and that there are projects to reduce water consumption.
"It is also relative, the water consumption of avocados is only a fraction of the water consumption of meat," says Adriëlle Dankier. "Everything that grows needs water. It's about whether there is enough water in the area to make it sustainable. You have to make conscious choices about it."
